etymologies: mid 17th century: from Greek anakhronismos, from ana- ‘backwards’ + khronos ‘time’

definitions: a thing belonging or appropriate to a period other than that in which it exists, especially a thing that is conspicuously old-fashioned

examples.text: everything was as it would have appeared in centuries past apart from one anachronism, a bright yellow construction crane

shortDefinitions: thing belonging or appropriate to period other than that in which it exists

definitions: an act of attributing a custom, event, or object to a period to which it does not belong

examples.text: it is anachronism to suppose that the official morality of the age was mere window dressing

shortDefinitions: action of attributing something to period to which it does not belong
